content.question: Which of the following best helps explain why the electronegativity of <math alttext="C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is less than that of <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>?

choices.label: The mass of the <math alttext="C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atom is greater than the mass of the <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atom.

The <math alttext="C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> nucleus contains more protons than the <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> nucleus contains.

When <math alttext="C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> form bonds with other atoms, the <math alttext="C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></math> bonding electrons are more shielded from the positive <math alttext="C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> nucleus than the <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> bonding electrons are shielded from the positive <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> nucleus.

Because <math alttext="C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is larger than <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the repulsions among electrons in the valence shell of <math alttext="C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> are less than the repulsions among electrons in the valence shell of <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: When <math alttext="C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> form bonds with other atoms, the <math alttext="C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></math> bonding electrons are more shielded from the positive <math alttext="C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> nucleus than the <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> bonding electrons are shielded from the positive <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> nucleus.

skill.text: 4.A: Predict and/or explain chemical properties or phenomena (e.g., of atoms or molecules) using given chemical theories, models, and representations.
